125564720.review: Sakura Angels, the second Visual Novel by developers Winged Cloud, is another fan-service heavy story with a male protagonist and several normal and supernatural women around him. The protagonist this time is apparently a normal teenager when he gets attacked by a monster on his way to school. He is saved by two women who turn out to be angels and suddenly also appear in his school as classmates. Soon, a third woman enters the scene, apparently a demon or succubus, who has sent the monsters after the protagonist in the first place. Several flirts and some choices later, the game explores the theme of being ignored during teenage years, but falls flat doing so. Sakura Angels is not a deep game, but presents a bit more choice than Sakura Spirit and is slightly more engaging. Visuals are on the same level, and voice acting is available in Japanese. Despite this, Sakura Angels is still a very lacklustre way to spend time, and not a good Visual Novel at all.

104331381.review:
Sakura Angels is a visual novel which isn't overly deep, there isn't a large selection of girls to choose from, and as far as I can tell, your choices only affect the very ending of the game, other than some dialogue changes directly after the decision. It's definitely not a deep game as far as visual novels go, and as far as the storyline is concerned, I wouldn't say it's *bad*, but there are definitely plotholes. 

However, there is quite humourous dialogue which leads to an enjoyable read, and if, like probably 90% of players, you're playing for the fanservice, the game definitely has that. There isn't any direct nudity in this game however, so that's something you may want to know before you buy it. 

Overall I'd recommend it if you're looking for a quick, not deep but also not bad plotline, or just looking for the fanservice, however I would say buying during a sale is probably best (Something which happens a lot with these games anyway). And yes, I really just wrote a serious review for this game.

Sakura Angels takes the concept of guardian angels and makes it literal, in the form of two cute, clingy girls who do anything to protect you. Well, when they're not stumbling over their own breasts or losing their clothes in freak tentacle accidents 🙈

The art and music is very pleasing, and the story is an upgrade from Sakura Spirit. More choices, and several endings! That said, there's still the trademark typos and oversights that makes the product feel rushed 😵

But we do get not just one, not just two, but *three* scenes of the protagonist walking in on the girls. And that's a bold move worth applauding 🥇

Enjoyable enough, though I see untapped potential that I hope is addressed in future Sakura games! ⭐

73230606.review:
[h1]Follow our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36214917/]Curator Group for more reviews[/url][/h1]
Sakura Angels is a visual novel that puts a lot of effort towards the visuals and almost no effort towards the novel. It’s essentially softcore porn with a nonsensical plot.

The story only serves to move the main character around the city so he can see scantily clad anime girls. There is also a lot of cringeworthy dialogue that is only there to appeal to the “nice guy” demographic. Without getting into plot specifics, every character is written quite poorly. The villain is primarily motivated by loneliness, while the two angels seem to begin the story already in love with you. The romance doesn’t make any sense because the story takes place over the course of what seems like a week.

The visuals are drawn well, but are obviously in a weird, over-the-top style. I assume that someone into anime porn would enjoy them, although it seemed like there was only a handful of porn images. Honestly, you are probably better off just googling hentai if that’s what you are looking for, rather than wading through a terrible story just for a glimpse of anime porn.

This game has a lot of issues and I don’t really understand why anyone enjoys these. If you want nude anime girls, you can look at that for free online somewhere, and if you want an interesting story, there are plenty of genuinely good visual novels available.

2/10

69994841.review:
Sakura Angels (2015) is WingedCloud's second Visual Novel. This is a LOT better than Sakura Spirit (2014), but still pretty average overall.

Dialogue is a lot better. There are actually choices and a couple of story branches. There is even a bit of animation with the sprites. Music seems to be on the same level of quality as Sakura Spirit; Well written but just a MIDI file that sounds artificial. 

I want to point out that the dialogue is fully voiced in Japanese - something I found interesting considering WingedCloud is not a Japanese game developer. The voices are done well and it adds a lot to the experience.

Storyline wise... its short.... which isnt necessarily bad as it makes this a nice break from hardcore games. But its pretty cookie-cutter. All its elements (much like Sakura Spirit) feel like they were lifted from other anime and manga and pasted back together. Zero originality.

67465019.review:
Sakura Angel is the 2nd Sakura title from the Winged Cloud. 
As usual, it is a short Visual Novel. Also, similarly to the previous game, we have some light fantasy elements, but this time within contemporary setting. It is an action comedy with a faint love triangle and lots of fanservice. A relatively standard story with standard tropes and standard conclusion. Only decent if you have seen little anime, otherwise it is completely predictable.
The story offers a few choices which lead to a few slightly different endings so it's not a kinetic novel. To complete the gallery you will need to get all endings.
Wanaca's art, present in all Sakura games, is one of the best aspects of this VN. It is fairly detailed and colourful. Backgrounds are generally up to standards.
The music is acceptable and mostly fits the accompanying scene. Nothing memorable, though.

Overall, the game has a very average story with a decent art and typical tropes. Barely recommendable even if you really like light fantasy setting: 5/10.

60005991.review:
Sakura Angels is the second game from Sakura series by Winged Cloud. There is a bit more emphasis on the story this time with a little bit darker theme compared to Sakura Spirit. It is still a fairly short VN (around 6 hours) with couple of fanservice scenes here and there but definitely less than previous instalment.

Our MC Kenta is your typical average high school student who has been having some severe headaches which are directly tied to his nightmares he has been having lately. But there seems to be more to it than meets the eye...
One morning when Kenta is on his way to the school, he is assaulted by some kind of shadow monster and that's where our heroines appear to save the day. 2 guardian angels, Hikari and Sayaka who has been secretly protecting Kenta.

Sayaka is cheerful and always optimistic while Hikari is typical Tsundere, prone to violence when trying to hide her embarrassment. Both girls are fully voiced this time which is nice change compared to Sakura Spirit. The voice acting is good enough but not the best I have heard.

There are quite a bit of choices you can make during the game and some of them affect the ending you will see but the diferences are not that big. There are 3 posible ending variations.

Music this time wasn't as good as with previous title but still decent enough for most parts.

Visuals are pretty good with some added effects and nice CG gallery. All the background images and sprites were of good quality.

Overall, I would recommend the game if you want some short and quite funny VN but better to wait for a sale since the discounts for this game are pretty good.

44647078.review:
Sakura Angels Review

A Different, but beautiful adventure lies in wait.

Some key points that this game offers:

1.	Amazing story line filled with Love, Romance, and Laughter and various other emotions.
2.	A book that has come alive
3.	Amazing artwork and detail, stunning background art.
4.	A soothing but comfortable background soundtrack.
5.	Various options making the game experience an impressive and enjoyable one.

Gameplay & Controls: 

The controls are pretty straightforward, you click to proceed with each script piece, or you can enable auto proceed and the scripts continue by themselves as you read through them at a pace you can enjoy. 

There are various shortcuts to enhance the game experience all which can be found under the menu options. 
The gameplay is fairly simple since this is a visual novel you either use one button to move the script onwards or you set it to move as you read at your own pace, that’s all there is to it.

Graphics:

Absolutely stunning details all over, the static background images are a marvel, incredible detail can be found in every scene, every little aspect is decently depicted with incredible accuracy. The NPC or characters in game have that same effect. 

A lot of beautiful detail went into each one to give them their own unique look and appearances making them beautiful and very enjoyable to look at, The graphics in this game are truly a work of art. Under the menu options we have the means to choose window or full screen mode.

Sounds:

To accompany stunning art they added incredible music, every scene or place in the game has beautiful background music accompanying it, from soothing music to nostalgia inducing, the music truly makes this game great. 

It adds a lovely sense of calm as you enjoy the story line.

Replayability:

The game has certain choices you can choose from, but that isn’t really a reason to replay it, the game however can be replayed, we all reread a book once in a while, especially if it was a good one.

The fun part here is that you can have it move pages on its own as you sit back and enjoy the story line again and again, so yes this game has a means of replayability even though it’s a different one from what we are used to.


MGR Gaming’s Conclusions:
Spoilers ahead:

The graphics and sound come together incredibly, if you couple that with the amazing story line, we have ourselves a work of art that everyone who enjoys reading will absolutely adore, it truly is that beautiful.  The more you play the more you want to play; you can get lost in the story line, and given how amazing the game looks via the art work and that amazing music you really do get lost in this epic visual novel.

Since this is a book and giving away the plot will ruin it, I won’t share too much regarding the story line, to keep it as short as possible, your ancestors sealed away an ancient evil spirit and now it and its forces are after you, why you ask? Well that you will have to find out as you delve deep into this amazing game, but fret not you are accompanied and protected by two beautiful and magical ladies whose duty is to protect you, so you are not alone.

Steam has this game tagged as Nudity and Mature, so expect to see some form of nudity, depending on where you are from, nudity ratings may vary, so for the sake of caution the game was tagged containing nudity. Expected nudity that can be seen here would be naked characters with exposed breasts but no exposed nipples. Her backside can also be seen but her bottoms in not in any compromising position.

Score 8

44214192.review:
Sakura Angels is an ecchi visual novel, second entry in the Sakura series by developer Winged Cloud. While retaining its main comedic and ecchi tone, it sports a slightly more elaborate story and character development compared to Sakura Spirit. By focusing on just two girls, their personalities and interactions shine thorugh much more clearly, resulting in better immersion and player involvement. It's much easier to grow to like the two girls, to laugh at their antics and to pick your waifu. There's also a few more choices, some meaningless and some adding up to one of three different endings. I'll say that it did give me a few good laughs and involve me enough with the girls.

However, it's still mostly a cavalcade of clichés, there's even less in terms of "juicy material" than in Sakura Spirit, and the art is cute and charming but still not good enough to justify the purchase alone. I'd consider it better than its predecessor, if only for the much more entertaining and memorable story, but it's still nothing more than a silly little distraction.

Again: not bad at all, just a little… meaningless.

Okay look, it has been a while since i last played this game so what i am about to say may be a slight variation of the actual story. You play as Mr. Generic, Genericson, look, it's the typical VN protagonist, it's not important. You play as stupid guy, and one night while walking home you encounter this creature, or shadow rather. But before it get's a chance to munch on your bones two Angels come and rescue you. I am sure you can guess what they look like from the store page. Throughout the story you will go to school with these angels and you will encounter a dark angel that will try to kill you. You will of course also be able to choose the best girl, which ever one that might be. 

[h1]Grammar:[/h1]
This is a section that i always dread when it comes to VN's but since it's from Winged Cloud and they have some competent writers, it's decent and i didn't encounter any errors. So good on them on that.

[h1]The Art/Visuals:[/h1]
I know this point may seem pointless since you can just look at the screenshots, but i still wanted to leave my thoughts on it. It's good, and it's high quality, which is expected from Winged Cloud, since they sure have more than enough money to spend on it. The art style is in their typical iconic art style that we have seen every time. Please i know that this is a older VN from Winged Cloud but that doesn't make it any less true. 

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
It's an okay Visual Novel. However i do have to say that for the amount of content that you are given, 10€ is far, far too much. I can absolutely not recommend it for that price. Wait for it to go down to 5€ or less. Then it would be worth it, otherwise, not a chance in hell. But if you look away from the price, it's a okay VN. It's nothing special at all. Not even close, but if you want something dumb to spend a couple hours on then sure, i am not stopping you.

[spoiler]Also for those that are wondering. The VN does not have a 18+ patch so if you want to buy it for the patch then i am sorry to tell you but this is not one of them. If you want the 18+ patches you should check out their more recent VN.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Wanaca's Art.
    [*]Voice Acting.
[/list] 

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Poor Visual Feedback.
    [*]Lack of Portrait action and variety.
    [*]Forgettable story, horrible writing.
    [*]BGM is generic.
    [*]Bad editing.
    [*]Meaningless Choices to make.
[/list] 
_______________________________

Sakura Angels is an Ecchi Visual Novel that is a spiritual sequel to Sakura Spirit, despite the former ending with a cliffhanger.
This marks the start of the Sakura games by Winged Cloud as a Franchise, with every game they release taking place on different realities.

In Sakura Angels you assume the role of Kenta, who finds himself endangered by mysterious witch and an ancient evil, sealed away long ago by his ancestors. Enter Sayaka and Hikari, two Magical Girls in charge with keeping Kenta safe.

The characters are cliché, Sayaka is cheerful(genki girl), Hikari is a  tsundere and Kenta is the normal, semi-weak male.
As with Sakura Spirit I find writing lacking and poor, in fact I enjoyed Sakura Angels less than its predecessor, the main character’s motivation didn’t seem to have the same sense of urgency Spirit did and as consequence it the story is even more of a chore to read.
Sakura angels ending feels rushed, another thing the previous titles as in common, like the devs were tired of it and wanted to end the game tying things up in any way possible, turning the antagonist the most disappointing aspect of the writing, with her reasons being childish and delivering us another anti-climatic ending, with our heroes unexpectedly becoming exponentially more competent and dispatching the evil entity with minimal effort.

Editing and presentation are lacking too, while the writing seems better and feels more cohesive than Sakura Spirit, it still suffers from a plethora grammatical mistakes and awkward phrasing.
There is also many instances where the text overflows the text box and sometimes it even is overlaped by the rest of the User Interface.

The choices are plenty, but have no impact providing only a few lines of different dialogue for each choice, it took me 3 Hours to see everything the game had to offer, every choice, every dialog.

As for the BGM, it seems more generic this time around and much less immersive than what was present on Sakura Spirit. The visual novel does include Voice Acting which is a big plus, but the text/voice sync is weird and badly done, in many instances I had to wait for the girls to finish talking before the text was displayed.

The art is great, the backgrounds and the girls are well drawn but that is the only redeeming factor of this visual novel, like the previous title though, there's lack of variety on both, backgrounds and characters, and also a disconect of what's happening on the story and what's shown on the screen.



[h1]Final Thoughts:[/h1]
In short, Angels suffers from the same incompetent storytelling and structure with Wanaca's Art being the sole redeeming factor, the inclusion of voice acting does provide a bit of immersion but it's not much of an improvement over Sakura Spirit, mainly when the rest is static or worse in comparison. 

It is a shame since it did have a nice, even if cliche and overdone idea, but they chose not to develop it further, making it a shallow and skip-able Visual Novel, do you like the art? Then go to Winged Cloud Patreon or contact Wanaca and try to buy access to her art instead, this game is not worth the cost.

Me sorprendo cada vez que empiezo un nuevo juego de esta serie... y es que ya sé lo que me voy a encontrar, historias malas, personajes lamentables y un esquema que se repite una y otra vez.

Afortunadamente, también me encuentro con los dibujos de Wanaca, y esto suele ser suficiente para que me anime a empezar un nuevo Sakura.

En ésta ocasión nos encontramos con otra Novela visual en la que no tenemos muchas decisiones que tomar la verdad, pero por si sirve de algo, diré que podemos conseguir tres finales distintos (muy parecidos entre si). Nos ponemos en la piel de Kenta, un joven estudiante que sin comerlo ni beberlo se encuentra en el punto de mira de una extraña fuerza oscura...

Afortunadamente, contará con la protección de dos jovencitas bastante locas que por alguna razón caerán víctimas de sus encantos (y esto no hay quien lo entienda, porque Kenta es la viva definición del tío-muermo).

A partir de ahí... situaciones ridículas y poco más... un final apresurado y la sensación de que esas 5 horas de juego solo han servido para disfrutar de los dibujos de Wanaca y poco más, y es que hay que decir que pese a su conocida exageración, los dibujos de éste juego son muy, muy bonitos. Y digo "bonitos" con todo lo que la palabra implica, el que quiera material subido de tono lo encontrará en mayor o menor medida, pero también gustará a quienes simplemente disfruten de unos dibujos bien hechos (que no proporcionados).

Una musiquilla machacona que nos recordará a cualquier otra entrega de la saga y que no nos hará temblar de emoción ni mucho menos, y listos, otro juego finalizado.

Pero a pesar de todo esto, le daría un punto positivo (me entretiene, que es lo que cuenta, a pesar de sus muchas carencia) si no fuera porque nuestro personaje es COMO TODOS los protagonistas de la saga, un tipejo estúpido, antipático y más tonto que un pomelo.

Parece mentira que escondan la necesidad de plantear escenas subidas de tono bajo la estupidez de un personaje que no se entera absolutamente de nada lo que pasa a su alrededor, un psicólogo tendría mucho trabajo para tratar a cualquiera de estos mindundis que son absolutamente incapaces de empatizar con nadie y que encima, atraen a toda fémina que se acerque a su área de influencia.

Decir que Kenta es absolutamente insoportable, es quedarse corto, pero como no es el primer Sakura que "juego", voy a intentar no echarle más tierra encima y os dejaré el dudoso honor de poder descubrirlo por vosotros mismos... si os da por jugar el juego, claro.

36063731.review:
tl;dr: Pretty fun, Vibrant art, okay story.  8/10

Having already completed Sakura Spirit before this one in my crusade to finish all of the Sakura games (that is in order of release date as well as earning all of the pictures in the gallery), I was excited to see improvements that would come about in Sakura Angels.  This review won't be a compairson of the two, seeing as they're two ENTIRELY seperate games, but I will be using my experiences from Spirit to gague the experiences in Angels.

PLOT (Mostly spoiler-free):

The story of Angels is rather dark and serious compared to the bubbly soundtrack and vibrantly-colored art.  You assume the role of Tenka, a high school student who is suffering from a reoccuring dream and splitting headaches.  As he is walking to school one day, he is attacked by a monster.  Just before he is killed, his two "guardian angels", Sayaka and Hikari, show up to save him.  Without spoiling too much, you learn the reasons behind Tenka's dreams and headaches, and go about solving those problems.  Your dynamic...trio...has a lot to offer up in personality.  Sayaka is loud an happy, but also has a streak of evil mischief to her.  Hikari is quiet and bossy, but has adorable moments of genuine happiness.  The two play off each other, and you, quite well, and they had me laughing in several scenes.  I felt engaged by the conflict, and wanted to see it resolved with great curiosity.  It's a great feeling when you slowly feel yourself sucked into a narritive, and Sakura Angels had my full attention.

ART:

Look, when it comes to the anime art style in games, you either love it or you hate it.  I found that the art in this particular game had such vibrancy and emotion, that it embodied the characters they were reflecting.  Pictures of Sayaka were bright and almost always in motion, and pictures of Hikari were a bit duller, but her bright color palette represented her hidden softer side.  For a game with no existing explicit patch, the art felt more erotic than it should.  In fact, you're greeted with a full-on shot of Sayaka's rear in one scene.  The art felt carefully planned out in a sense.  Tenka never had large, over the top, "anime" reactions to seeing the girls half-naked, so the eroticism in the art felt a bit more subtle.  Even if you might not be the biggest fan of the anime-styled games, I'm sure there's a pic or two in the gallery that will make you smile or otherwise..

MUSIC:

The soundtrack to Angels was par for the game itself.  Happy scene, bubbly music.  Serious scene, ominous music.  Fight scene, electric guitars.  The soundtrack wasn't so awful that I had to mute the music, but it was never good enough that I wished that there was a soundtrack available for it.  Mostly, it just faded into the background until I heard it switch.  I guess that could be considered a failure, but I digress.

OVERALL EXPERIENCE:

It took me about 4 hours to complete the gallery in Sakura Angels.  Unlike Spirit, you have a choice of 3 endings.  You can choose to favor Sayaka, Hikari, or neither, and it changes your ending scenes.  The choices to decide whose route you are going to be on are sprinkled throughout, and all you need to do is pick enough choices (that's 3 out of 4) to favor one of the girls.  Pick an even distribution of choices for them, and you get the neutral ending.  I suppose the choices don't matter much, seeing as the ending is very brief, but I felt myself desiring to see how each of them played out and how they would affect the other character.  Unfortunately, there were a few other nitpicky things that bugged me as I did this.  The voice acting (which was a welcome addition) felt like it was recorded in someone's bedroom or garage.  Some scenes had so much echo, that it was impossible to ignore.  Also, when I would foward onto the next line of dialogue before the voices were complete, the sound would stutter, and I even experienced a crash while skipping some already-read dialogue.  I would like to attribute some of these failures to my computer, but it's unclear as to what caused it.  The voice acting...that's nothing that a better computer can fix.

So in conclusion, the four hours I poured into this game were full of smiles and laughs.  The plot seemed rigid enough that I didn't feel unsatisfied.  Even with the minor issues I had, the adventures of Tenka, Sayaka, and Hikari were a blast!  The game's writing really makes the experience enjoyable through the entire time.  Currently (As of October 27th, 2017), the game is on sale for 2.99 USD.  For just three dollars, you can dip your toes into this game, and hopefully get pulled in as much as I did.  I wouldn't recommend skipping this Sakura titie, if not for just the writing and dialogue alone!

35500523.review:
What is nice about Sakura Angels, is that you get almost exactly what you expect : a basic fantasy story with mild fanservice straight out of the classic tropes of anime.

Clichés can be fun when used correctly. Here, they don't contradict one another, and work together without feeling too forced. This is why I could find some enjoyment in this visual novel.

Like the other times I have recommended visual novels, this is a condition-based thing.
[b]Sakura Angels is all about giving you something you already love. If you don't like anime/manga or if you're just tired of seeing similar archetypes and tropes, this game isn't for you.[/b]

But if you are willing to revel in the classic tropes and clichés, then there is  some fun to have here : some lines can genuinely trigger a laugh, and the addition of competent Japanese voice acting makes the characters way more enjoyable than those of silent visual novels. 

The game is overall a big step up from the previous "Sakura" visual novel I have played : Sakura spirit. 

In Sakura Angels, not only do we get those great voices, but the player now has way more choices than the singular one of the older game : even though the main story is pretty linear again, the player can at least chose some dialogue options now, and the ending will change a bit according to which girl you decided to give more attention to.

I say "giving attention", because really, this visual novel isn't truly a dating simulation. It's more of a small fantasy story where you can lean towards a girl in the process. 
Sakura Angels only has 2 girls you can truly interact with. This small number is both a problem and a quality. Less girls means the story is more focused : we don't get scenes that come out of nowhere so every girl can get the spotlight.
This can be a problem if you don't like either of the girls. But since the two girls are classic anime opposites (the "tsundere" and the "genkiko"), you should most likely lean naturally towards one.

My main complaint is the lack of character poses and illustrations when it comes to depicting the action scenes. Most of the magical spells are left entirely to your imagination, and you barely see the girls actually using their (classic but) kickass weapons. You only get text for all that.

I am aware that visual novels are very small indie projects. And because we got the big improvement of having voiceover, I will not thumb down the game for that lack of "event art". Still, I truly wish the battles would have been given more pictures and effects. Especially the final, climactic one.

Sakura Angels is all about providing classic stuff at a cheap price. But sometimes this is what we want. It's up to you to see if you can enjoy again what you enjoyed before several times, despite the limitations of the medium and the budget. 

...And if you are part of the crowd who never enjoyed that kind of manga, just stay very far away from this. This is clearly a product by fans, for fans.

First of the Sakura Visual Novel games I have played. And probably the worst Visual Novel I have played. While the worst from my perspective it does have a lot of good points! Just a few issues that really dragged this title down for me. 

Update: I've played three Sakura visual novels and this is THE WORST! (Changed to down vote as Winged Cloud have better titles and here are much better visual novels out there).

The score:

Story          2.00/4.00
Art              1.50/2.00
Audio         0.75/1.00
Mechanics 2.00/2.00
Characters 0.50/1.00

Total ==     6.75/10.00

The issues:

- Sayaka's voice actually hurts. The high pitch from some of her lines just make me cringe in pain

- Extremely predictable!

- Lack of branching paths that "change" the story. 

- It's a linear story with 3 different endings. However, the gallery images just don't feel worth it. (But it's good to see some form of branch)

- Fight scenes felt pretty poor. I'd rather just see some art pieces showing our angels fight the villian. (This some what does fix itself later into the game).

- Story dies out over time to the point where I got bored and I wanted the game to just end.

The Good! :D

- Art style is excellent for both characters and backgrounds.

- "Particular" images show our beautiful angels in multiple forms of clothing and poses. As expected for a Sakura game.

- Good to see some differet endings. Although, still a linear story.

- The User Interface (UI) is absolutely wonderful! Excellent Graphical UI (GUI) layout. Smooth interface. Lots of save allocations. Perfect for speed readers, slower paced readers and readers following the character's audio.

Conclusion:

I cannot recommend this for multiple replays. I found myself feeling tortured when closing towards the ending. I am rather dissapointed with this game.

However! This game gets a positive review from myself because it passes the line. It's not terrible. It functions and has content. And there is no option for an inbetween thumbs up or down vote.

Why do people like these games?
I understand people like pictures with their reading (Reading Rainbow is an essential cinematic masterpiece of our time), but I can't understand why they'd want to be berated by fictional women all the while exacerbating their carpel tunnel.
The whole time I was "playing" this I was trying to figure out what the appeal of it is. I'm a fan of anime, I used to enjoy the harem genre, but became disillusioned by it once the genre began to suffer from "Pokémon Protagonist Pity", i.e., the protagonist is just such a dumb and dense shit that never learns anything from the ridiculous experiences and obvious tells of unwarranted affection from multitudes of females and/or other side characters. (There are of course anime with harems where the protagonist has earned his adulation, yet rejects advances anyway intentionally, those are usually fun, however.)
I'm not even going to bother describing the game, because I'd be wasting both of our times telling you exactly what you know already about it from the rest of this genre, nor do I remember anything more than one was tsundere, the other was an idiot, and the villain reminded me of my mother; I've heard people say this isn't the "best example out there" of a VN, but I've also been given that spiel about almost everything I've ever disliked.

I've heard the VN with the disabled girls is one of the best, and is excellent at drawing emotion from the "player", but in situations of me crying at literature, I'd prefer it be something I can tell my mom about. 
Now I'm not saying your taste is bad -it's implied-, but everyone has differing opinions on the criteria constituting what a "game is", e.g., "an end-state", "an interactive story", or "real action I'm in control of", and I don't feel like any of that from this type of game is given to me. Yes, there's an end-state, but I don't sit there and say "Damn, that was an end-state", I instead say, "Did I seriously just click 450 times to be told that shit and get like 8 erotic images, I can get better erotic images without even having to click anymore with Google Assist", I'm not saying the conclusion was bad, it's exactly what I was expecting: uninteresting, just like this genre.
Thanks for reading and God bless.

26124067.review:
Primero que nada, si compraste este juego por mas de $20 cometiste un grave error y hechaste a la basura mas dinero del que debiste. Si quieres ahorrarte el analisis completo pasa a la ultima parte donde doy mis conclusiones

El principal problema que tuve con este juego es que simplemente es demasiado promedio, es como cualquier otra novela visual que hayas visto. Con completa sinceridad digo esto, en cuanto se presentaron todos los personajes predije como se desarrollaria la historia. Chicas magicas que protegen al protagonista de otra chica magica que es a su vez sirviente de el verdadero antagonista que es malo porque simplemente es malo y quiere matar al protagonista porque es el elegido o algo asi. Y eso fue lo que obtuve.

1.- Duracion: es un juego increiblemente corto. Yo lo pude terminar en dos horas y si le das a la opcion de skip, dejandote solo elegir las opciones puedes terminar el juego en menos de 10 minutos.
2.- Personajes: crei que los personajes serian cliche y si bien esto es verdad en el caso de Kenta y Hikari (no mientan, ellos dos son el protagonista de cualquier anime harem y Hikari es cualquier otra chica tsundere) realmente me sorprendi con Sayaka, la cual en mi opinion es lo mejor de todo el juego. Mientras que el personaje de ambas era en su mayoria fanservice, Sayaka de hecho tenia una personalidad interesante y divertida a tal punto que siempre me sacaba una sonrisa y seguramente a muchos otros tambien. Debo decir que los disenos de Sayaka (en general) y de Yuzuki (forma chica magica) me gustaron, no por la cantidad de piel que muestren ni que tan desproporcionadamente grandes sean sus senos (chicos, tengan criterio, si un personaje muestra una excesiva cantidad de piel esta casi asegurado que no le daran importancia a su personalidad o historia, como fue el caso con Hikari en cuanto a personalidad y Yuzuki en historia). 
3.- Historia: ... Predecible, demasiado predecible. Honestamente quien no haya adivinado de que trataria no tiene analisis critico en absoluto o simplemente no conoce los cliches mas usados en novelas visuales. Otra cosa que agregar es que las elecciones que hagas no afectan en nada el desarrollo de la historia, unicamente te dan miniconversaciones diferentes tras cada eleccion y obviamente con quien te quedas en el final pero para ser honesto no los considero finales, no inicias una relacion con nadie, la historia termina igual y lo unico diferente repito son las conversaciones. Ahora siendo realistas, a alguien en serio le importa la historia en este juego?
4.- Banda sonora: Es basicamente la misma de cualquier otra novela visual, nada especial pero quiza te aburras de prisa considerando que es la misma musica usada en diferentes secciones. Creo que solo son 3 pistas en todo el juego pero afortunadamente no te hacen querer asesinar un perrito ni apagar el sonido y ya sea que apagues la musica o no sera lo mismo en tu experiencia de todas maneras
5.- Escenarios: de nuevo, lo mismo que cualquier otra novela visual. Cuarto del protagonista, comedor, escuela, playa, bosque. Estan mas vacios que el corazon de Electronic Arts (aceptenlo, son el diablo) y no hay nada de especial en ninguno de ellos. El unico que me llamo la atencion fue el de la playa y no porque fuera particularmente hermoso o llamativo sino por los efectos. Fuera de eso no hay nada mas que agregar.
6.- Reparto: En general las voces me parecieron adecuadas para cada personaje pero hubo una que resalto de las demas en mi opinion, la de Yuzuki. Su voz me parecio perfecta, hasta llegaria a decir que hermosa y era capaz de representar cada emocion que sentia a la perfeccion. La voz de Sayaka simplemente sonaba alegre siempre y Hikari era la de cualquier tsundere.
7.- Comparacion: si lo comparamos con otros juegos de la misma serie, Sakura, hay mejoras pero unicamente en el aspecto de la cantidad de opciones que puedes tomar pero tampoco es como que sea un milagro que salve el juego del poco contenido que tiene ni tampoco es que sea un cambio grande.

CONCLUSION
Pensaran que odio al juego con todo esto y la verdad es que... no realmente. No me malentiendan, el juego es demasiado corto y esto no es necesariamente algo malo pues hay otros juegos cortos que he disfrutado bastante pero en este caso hay tan poco contenido que no se le puede dejar pasar. En mi opinion la mejor palabra para describirlo es PROMEDIO. 

Nada grandioso ni nada horrible, no presenta nada nuevo en ningun aspecto y tampoco se besa el culo a si mismo como juegos mediocres que se creen el proximo Fate. No creo que se merezca toda la mierda que le lanzan pero si entiendo porque algunos odiarian el juego con su falta de contenido y una vez mas, lo promedio que es. Pero creo que no lo ven de esta manera: si no lo disfrutaste es porque simplemente no estaba hecho para ti. Si con solo leer de que trata y las imagenes del juego no te pudiste dar una idea de como seria entonces entiendo tu decepcion, pero si lograste deducir como seria y aun asi lo jugaste entonces no puedes quejarte pues la culpa es completamente tuya. El juego es obviamente para pervertidos que quieren un fap rapido y para nadie mas. Si esperabas encontrar una buena historia o personajes interesantes buscaste en el lugar equivocado. 

Para pasar el rato esta bien, sera cliche pero tiene todo lo que a los pervertidos les gusta y quien sabe, quiza te saque una que otra sonrisa pero a no ser que lo veas en un SUPER DESCUENTO no recomiendo que lo compres, con su corta duracion seria lo mismo que quemar tu dinero. Si lo compras a su precio completo o a mas de $20 quiere decir que en serio deseabas ver algo para tu fap diario y solo puedo decir... viejo, para algo existe el porno.

23688553.review:
[h1]After I played Sakura Spirit on a whim, I decided to give Sakura Angels a try. What a wild ride it was.[/h1]

[b]Have a little background information about my experience[/b]
Sakura Spirit was the opening game in the Sakura series, and amidst the endless tide of reviews containing "Hurr durr breasts", there were some actual positive reviews. So when the Visual Novel (V/N) went on sale, I bought it, installed it and fifteen minutes later I'd finished, honestly wishing there was more to it. Sakura Spirit was a genuinely, surprisingly, enjoyable intro to a full length V/N that could have been. 

The setting was alright, more than half the cast were quite good. Hell, even the boring humans weren't completely shit. And there was that hot demon goddess lady who didn't do much but was interesting enough for me to want to see more of her. Both literally and figuratively.

So, the bar being set fairly high for the Sakura Series, with it's nice art and decent characters, I was looking forward to the rest.

[b]So, Sakura Angels is good then, right?[/b]
NO, SAKURA ANGELS IS BAD.

Not good, in any way. Hell, not even the usually above par (which admittedly isn't a very high par for anime style art) artwork. Some scenes draw characters a little weirdly, usually the faces are strange and the heads are huge. To the art's credit, that Sayaka picture is pretty nice. You know the one. 

I can only assume all the good character designers have long since been fired from the Sakura Dev Group, because nary a single character in this has any interest or depth to them. Sayaka's energetic, mischevious character is entirely ruined by the protagonist being a fucking idiot. 

Hisaki (The other main girl) started out alright, but has almost 0 character progression what-so-ever, and what little progression she has is hidden in her specific ending, in which she smiles more than once ever. Not only is she a really mediocre tsundere at best, what little of interest she has is further ruined by the protagonist being a fucking idiot. 

Then there's the Third Girl, Yuzuki, whom I can only imagine was an after thought. She is potentially the most interesting, and not only because the other candidates set the bar so low. THEN SHE GOES AND RUINS HERSELF BY BEING "I'M SHIT AT LIFE AND CAN'T MAKE FRIENDS I HAVE SUCH A DEEP CHARACTER FEEL BAD FOR ME AS THE APPARENT ANTAGONIST". To Yuzuki's credit, she is the only character that isn't further ruined by the protagonist being a fucking idiot, since she does all the work herself.

Have I mentioned the protagonist? If I haven't, he's indescribably stupid, but if I had to try, I'd call him a fucking idiot in the most venomous way possible. He's the most rubbish, generic, bland player insert character I've seen in quite some time, and I've seen alot of V/Ns, both good and bad. One of the options seems to give him an anyeurism, as he completely forgets both the question he was asked a second ago, and the scene that is still presently unfolding before him. He's a fucking idiot.

The protagonist, however, sums up the V/N quite nicely; Sakura Angels is a dissapointing mess of many generic V/N traits and characters, and it certainly shows. These traits, of course, extend from manga and anna may, but the particular nuances of Sakura Angels are [i]very[/i] boring, generic V/N.

[b]Enough of the characters, what else?[/b]
The entire thing sets itself up to last a while, then comes to a grinding halt about an hour and a half in because the plot realises it hasn't got anything past intro. Antagonist explanation and dramatic ending are crowbarred in, the resulting mess ending in less than a week, story time. 

If you've picked one of the girls more than the other one, our fucking idiot prot will sort of declare his love for them (sort of), then they live happily ever after. 

If I need to point out that knowing your two stalkers and completely falling for them, stating that they've completely changed your life in unprecedented ways, all in less than four days, is completely stupid, then this story is probably for you, because you're equally as stupid as the whole ordeal. 

I'm fine with a bit of romance and taking a fancy to someone, but four whole days is not enough to base so much drama on. He should be barely friends with these people, let alone care for them so much.

[b]So yeah.[/b]
I was dissapointed by Sakura Angels. After setting the bar so surprisingly high with Sakura Spirit, Sakura Angels fails to live up to be an even acceptable V/N, let alone a good one. 

It's a shame. Really, it is. I know people will look at this review and think "Haha, what an idiot, it's a game about Boob Girls being Boob Girls.". To an extent, this is true, but I want everything to be the best it can possibly be, especially things I've had experience enjoying, and the Sakura Series is no exception to this.

[b]Also[/b]
They got Kurumi from Date A Live to voice Hisaki. Date A Live is my favourite anime, and I like Kurumi, but hearing her voice come through Hisaki's mouth weirded me out a bit, and ruined what little of worth the character had left. One can only assume that the Voice Actress read the script and saw it for the rubbish it was, putting at little effort in as she could get away with. 

This isn't a bash at Kurumi, by the way, her voice is fine, it's more me associating the voice with someone else.

22523173.review:
[h1]OVERVIEW[/h1]
Sakura Angels is yet another anime-themed high-school visual novel. The game tells the story of the protagonist, Kenta, a male high-school student suffering from headaches who one day encounters something dangerous and otherworldly, and is protected by two young angelic body guards, Sayaka and Hikari.

The setting is fairly familiar, seeming like countless other animes, mangas, and visual novels, but the story is well told and the characters are likeable. A couple of gratuitous panty shots give the game a slightly guilty feel, and add the 'mature' and 'nudity' tags to the Steam page, but really it's all harmless enough, and suprisingly fun.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The sets are nicely drawn, although I was a bit disappointed with how much they were repeated. One street scene, for example, looks the same on a fine sunny day as it does on a day on which the characters are complaining about how much it is raining.

The character graphics and occasional risque gallery shots of the three main female characters are all very nicely drawn and suitably attractive. Small animations add to the life of the characters, as do the character graphic overlays moving around the screen to follow the action as described in some scenes. Very nice!

[h1]Sound[/h1]
The music is relatively atmospheric and suits the story well.

The three main female characters all have nice Japanese voiceovers. Not being able to understand anything more than rudimentary spoken Japanese, I can't vouch for the accuracy, but they sounded okay to me.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Sakura Angels plays like any other visual novel. You read some text, click for the next paragraph, and look at the pretty pictures, occasionally making choices as the story presents them.

Unfortunately there's only really a small number of decisions that affect which ending you see, and even then you can't really 'lose' (there is no bad ending), but the game includes a useful 'skip' feature that allows you to rapidly move over areas of the story that you've already seen on previous playthroughs, making it only a small effort to go back and try the different options for that one important decision.

The story is fairly typical of the genre, but the writing is excellent for the most part; I only saw a handful of typos throughout. The story itself isn't really 'mature-themed'; it's only the inclusion of some fairly mild gallery shots that makes this Steam tag appropriate.

[h1]PROS AND CONS[/h1]

Pros:
+ Sayaka and Hikari are great fun
+ very nice art, particularly the characters
+ Japanese voices
+ trading cards
+ great writing quality

Cons:
- a bit short; I completed it in just over two hours, then spent another hour or so going back to see the other choices and what differences they made
- no achievements; these could have been easily included and mapped to each gallery shot, as a nice addition to the game
- the protagonist is a bit of a putz; I wanted to give him a slap in a few places in the story

[h1]CONCLUSION[/h1]
Sakura Angels is a good, fun anime visual novel. It's the first of developer Winged Cloud's visual novels that I've played so far, and I enjoyed it. I only wish it were a bit longer.

[h1]8/10[/h1]

21728864.review:
I want it to be noted up front that I do NOT recommend this as a GAME. I think that's important to keep in mind when looking at reviews on a gaming platform to realize that a visual novel is not a game. I'd also like to note that this review may contain minor spoilers on some of the general trends of the game, but I will do my best to avoid specifics for prospective buyers. I also turned off the music and sound effects, so I can't comment on those aspects either. With all of that in mind, please enjoy the rest of the review.

This is a visual novel, which means that explaining the story too much is going to outright spoil it. The basic plot is that you essentially are taking the perspective and role of the main character, Kenta, which I believe is still in high school but don't quote me on that detail as it could be later education. Anyways, he has been having intense headaches and sleeping horribly without understanding why. That is, until one day on the streets coming home from school when his intense headache is swiftly followed by an attack by a supernatural creature! Just when things are looking most grim, he is saved by a couple more supernatural beings. He finds himself in the hands of two guardian girls with magical powers that are tasked with protecting him from these evil creatures. Who are the creatures? Who are these two mysterious girls? What could all of this mean? Well, you'll have to find out for yourself.

I think it's important to explain why I DO recommend this title. The story is alright. I didn't find it to be anything spectacular, but it functions just fine. The various options and multiple pages open for saves are very convenient for managing your experience to your liking. Plus, there's even a skip function. This is helpful for replaying the game so that you can quickly skip over parts you've already experienced in order to get to the new parts faster. This is because you can actually make a few choices in the game that will effect the following events and ending. So using the skip function to test out different paths in the game is highly useful. There are some reused images for the characters and backgrounds, but every so often you'll be rewarded with a custom drawn image. This is where most of my enjoyment of the game comes from. I think the two main girls are very pretty. I mean, to be fair, a lot of the people looking at this game are looking at it for the promise of hot anime girls. I can say that it delivers. There are three attractive cartoon women to look at, with a few expressions, outfits, and custom pictures. All of the custom pictures can be found later in the gallery so you won't need to play through again just to see them. So, as the general fapping tool that it tries to market itself as, it works just fine. And hey, I even found myself getting somewhat invested in a couple of the characters.

However, let's address the shortcomings here. Again, the large selling point of sex appeal can't exactly be ignored. While it does work for some one-handed fun, I do think it could be a little lacking for most. There are mainly two girls you see the whole time. You see some of the third, but not nearly as much. Each one has a standard pose they're always in, with sometimes altering their poses slightly, changing their facial expressions, and a few costume changes. And, of course, they have their few custom pictures. This isn't bad, but I think there could've been some more variety, especially with the limited number of girls to gawk at. Plus, there's always the possiblity that you won't find any combination of the three attractive. Even finding just one unattractive takes a huge hit to that main selling point. I guess it's probably pretty shallow and harsh to judge such a thing, but I think it's very fair considering a large portion of the audience will be here for the obviously intended sex appeal. I do have to give it a little credit, though. Unlike Sakura Spirit, the characters feel a little more realistic in their actions and reactions rather then it being about tons of inuendos constantly being stamped out by an unbelievably decent protagonist. This time around you can at least feel that the girls are more restrained and the protagonist more human. It makes the title feel a lot more natural and compelling. I guess that's the trade-off, which may be a turn off to some.

I also took some issue with the in-game choices. I think the feature is nice and has some interesting results, but it feels out of place. You aren't really the main character here. The main character is Kenta, and he seems to have his own personality. You're just in his perspective. So when you make choices for him, it feels almost out of character. So either the story should've been more static and true to his character, or more open with choices and allowed you to be the main character instead. 

This next part gets a bit spoilery but stay with me if you're not too afraid, otherwise skip to the next section.

I also found that the three routes you can go weren't all satisfying. I think the best route is the neutral route where you don't have a preference for either of the main girls. The ending feels a lot more like the start of the game, wrapping it all up in a nice, familiar bow. I enjoyed the Hikari ending the most because I got the most attached to her. I felt like she was hard to get close to, but that she appreciates that relationship the most and it just felt so natural to want her. And the events that play out as a result all feel very natural. When I played it over again favoring Sayaka I felt bad. She seems so light and happy, but she has trouble listening to me half the time and it made Hikari seem a lot more lonely, jealous, and mean. It seems like Sayaka could make herself happy with or without me so it didn't feel like my feelings were mutual. Plus, she teasingly torments Hikari a lot, which seemed playful in the Hikari route but just plain mean in the Sayaka route. I also thought that having a Yuzuki route would've been nice. She seemed to have such a compelling backstory that I could've found myself feeling for her, but the game didn't offer that as an option. Her destiny is set in stone regardless of what you do, which is a real shame.

The biggest disappointment of all is just that this game ends with a lot of new questions and old questions unanswered. We still barely know much of anything about these magical beings. We don't know what will happen to the characters next. We barey started learning about Yuzuki. Whatever relationship you pick seems to lead to very little in the end aside from future possibilities. The main plot is resolved, but the end isn't necessarily satisfying. And I really was hoping for a kiss from Hikari... sigh. I guess we'll just have to cry for a sequel and hope it happens.

So why do I recommend it? Sure, it's by no means a game. It's a bit lacking in a few areas. It's not amazing. I recommend it because... well... not only did I have a fun time with it, and I know you know what I mean, but I also found myself caring about Hikari, a fictional character. Maybe that says more about me than it does this title, but it's something worth experiencing for yourself, regardless of who you get attached to. It's probably not worth the full ten bucks for most people, but get it on sale. Especially if you like the Sakura series in general. Besides, sometimes it's fun to give your fapping a little context.

20837940.review:
Sakura Angels is a short visual novel explaining the protagonist's adventure with his guardian angels to save the world from an ancient evil. It is another production by Winged Cloud, who have released several VNs with a similar aesthetic theme.

The storyline is not going to win any prizes for originality or scope; however, it is sufficient enough to drive the novel from start to finish. There aren't really any emotional investments made into the story, nor are there any distinct moral or philosophical undertones apparent; however, that does not detract from the experience, because the game does not necessarily try to construct a pretentious plot or theme. Instead, it is focused on providing a cute, entertaining experience for the reader, and in that regard it succeeds. There are some choices made in the game, but as far as I can tell they don't really have too much of an impact on the final story. The characters are not deep, but that doesn't detract from the story; I still found the characters to be entertaining and loveable.

The artwork is quite nice. The protagonist's guardian angels are both cute and well dressed, being presented in several different outfits over the course of the novel. The background images themselves are also pleasing. The artwork of the monsters, however, leaves a little to be desired, although the antagonist is sufficiently well presented in her own right. One aspect of the story I wish was more presented is combat; there is no real effort made on screen to make the characters appear to be engaged. The erotic artwork also borders on the rediculous; then again, there is probably a significant clientele that is looking for such an exposure in this game, so I don't hold it against the novel. Nonetheless, I was pleased with the quality of the artwork and find it to be beautiful and enjoyable to see.

I thoroughly enjoyed the music as well. While you may not experience such music as John Williams or Hanz Zimmer, the novel has an engaging and pleasing soundtrack that fits well with the game. The only complaint in this regard is that some of the music during combat scenes was not used to its full potential.

The novel's length is short -- about two hours or so. I am, however, a very quick reader, so your own experience may be closer to three hours or more.

Overall, I would recommend this visual novel as long as you know what to expect from it. While it may not be a masterpiece of the visual novel genre, you will be entertained for several hours. I guess if you are into the erotic aspect of it, that is an added bonus too; however, my recommendation doesn't require that you desire that part of the novel in order to enjoy it. I didn't buy it for its near-nudity, and still enjoyed it; nonetheless, with its price point at $10, I would advise waiting until it goes on sale before making the purchase.

20620359.review:
Well... After the absolute bunk that Sakura Swim Club was, my initial plan was (unless it's, specifically, a Sakura Fantasy title) to never touch another Winged Cloud product again...but, it turns out that I had bought this thing on a sale at some point.

So, I'll address the pros first, as few as they are. To be perfectly fair, it's an improvement. Maybe, it's the fact that they couldn't try to excuse abysmal writing and terrible production value with nudity, but... Whatever the case, it's a step in the right direction. A small and shaky step made by a drunk dog onto the surface of a recently frozen lake, but a step forward, at least. 

Now that credit given where it's due, I still have to say that it's not enough to justify a recommendation. 
The writing, while certainly a step up over Swim Club, does a passable job of building things up...just in time to wrap everything up in what I can only describe as a premature ejaculation. Everything having been transfered to the "being up and resolved" train, having forgotten "pacing" and "flow" at the station.
The music is better, though hardly anything notable. 
The art...well...it worked the first time around, until I realized that the character models are, quite literally, being recycled through every game. 

In short, Winged Cloud, keep trying with these side projects. Maybe, one day, you'll work up to having your products be on par with something like what a studio like Frontwing can produce. 

P.S. Where the hell is Sakura Fantasy Chapter 2? Considering how Fantasy is only passable product you've released, why do you keep on repeatedly distracting yourself with all this side crap?

19677614.review:
I really struggle to even call this a game.  I've played several other "visual novels" and by comparison Sakura Angels falls flat.  Gameplay consists largely of clicking through text.  There are perhaps a half dozen prompts that allow interaction beyond reading and clicking for the next text to pop up.  The graphics, limited voice acting, and music are the only redeeming qualities of this "game".

Overall the story of Sakura Angels is mediocre.  If this was an anime I'd probably turn it on while I worked on something else but the overarching story involving the protagonist is full of anime fanboy tropes and cliches.  Most of the other characters are so incredibly one-dimensional and function more as props than full-blown characters.

I might buy this for half the given price as a distraction and to have the music and screenshots.  Otherwise, I suggest players pass and try out other visual novels that offer more interactivity than Sakura Angels, otherwise there is plenty of manga/anime out there that offers better stories and won't result in carpal tunnel.

17962989.review:
Okay, allow me to be clear. Sakura Angels isn't breaking records. It's fun to imagine what is actually happening animation style in your head. The cute Japanese voices definitely help give you a good image on how the characters would walk, move, interact and the like. The CG is beautiful. And the writing gets you giggling. The story doesn't take itself too seriously, and why should it? I'm not going to give any spoilers, but these girls definitely aren't culinary masters.

And now for me to complain a bit - Why is the CG so disconnected from the writing? It's a visual novel, if you're going to put the protagonist in particular situations, why not draw it? Yes, our imaginations are the ones that need to work here. But black screens would have been enough if you wanted that. There are so many points in the story where I really wanted to see what was happening. It's a visual novel, so let me see what I'm reading! Not to mention how many unanswered questions I have...

That aside, I'm glad I picked this up at the five dollar price. I can say that the tease is only worth that much. But pick it up if you can, because it's a mighty good tease, and there's going to be more, so support the artists and creators so that they can support us, and give us more of what we need. A deeper story with more characters (wouldn't mind seeing some male characters for diversity. There needs to be something there to make the story more intersting!) More CG to depict the various parts of the story (Be a visual novel more) and perhaps be clear with your aim for the choices. If they could branch more and allow the story to take different directions, that'd make the story fun to play multiple times. Or just make your story longer, and leave the choices as spice to make scenes slightly different. Either way it was a joy to read, and I definitely want more.

TL;DR version: Get it while it's cheap. It's worth the laugh, the awe and the distraction. Just not the full ten dollars.

16694368.review:
So I didn't really like the Sakura Series as a whole, but I got this game as a gift and might as well do a review on it. Let's get started I guess. Take note, where I might be saying some aspect is bad in an aspect of the game, I did not mostly take into account everything else. I was looking at each aspect individually.

Story - 5/10
The "Plot" wasn't good. Really. There were a couple of cringy moments at the start of the novel that made me want to drop it instantly. For example, the overuse of the Protaganist thoughts during times like when they first met Yuzuki was really cringy and uneeded. The only reason I stayed was for the so called "romantic" choices with Sayaka or Hikari, and storyteller really butchered it. (I wanted a kiss scene. Why. ;~;)

Most romance/(insert any genre here) has to have a kiss scene or at least something really... (kawaii? Moe?) to make up for it at the end or any kind of build up. Not to mention that the romance build up between Hikari and the MC, since I only played her route, not too keen on doing Sayaka's since I don't like her character (N-Not that I like Tsunderes okay! There wasn't any Dandere/Kuuderes...) was really bad...  

I mean, all you did was talk to her on the roof, even thought it wasnt much, then waltz in on her in bathroom and what, chose her over Sayaka at the beach? Theres wasnt much buildup to make her go all "caring" after you, and even throw away her so-called "Tsundere" attitude... Felt too rushed for that.


Gameplay - 7/10
Considering that this is an english-based indie game made by developers from all over the world, the gameplay is actually pretty good. Then again I have been playing games from some I guess the "most publicised" and (AAA?) companies like Pulotte and Sprite, my standards were kind of high...

But you need to work up the choices better in my opinion. How? Like you should have maybe, just maybe, given a chance to kiss her.. (I want kawaii~ The art works so well with this! Voice Actors aren't really that needed. Thought it will be a huge gain.)

Art - 8/10
Now, I'm pretty sure overall everyone came because of the art. I mean, it's the only thing that appealing to this game and mostly th reason why people want to see how to the story came out. The art is great. Real great. Tons of fanservice though, not exactly what I wanted. But it was to appeal to the main crowd here on Steam so I guess it's normal. Oh, and the enviroment was well animated. Why? Have you not notice the sunlight filtering down, literally, on the rooftop, and the animated sea on the beach? Now that was nice. Almost felt like NekoPara there. Hue.

However, there was a few flaws tho. Scenes like the "Cafeteria being crowded" with a really empty cafeteria is kinda... not there. I get it that the alternative is to have some sort of imagination. But really, you should have draw people inside to really emphasize on this.. 
True, it's pretty hard to draw, since I'm a Game Artist-in-study myself, and trying to get the poportions according to how far the perspectives are is pretty hard. Then again, maybe you devs should have taken more time to spread out your deadline for games and really work on each aspect of the game, then we might have gotten a better impression of  you guys. 


Overall Conclusion- 6/10
With all these fast games coming out so fast, and then patches for Voice Actors and all coming after, I really think your just looking to milk us of our money with this games. I mean, the story wasn't thought out well enough, none of the background art to be put together properly, It all points to fast deadlines and stuff. 

Which makes me wonder why would you want to have fast deadlines? Why all the need for this? The only logical reason for all of this is basically to milk us of our money to have funds. But for what, I don't know. Maybe they need some base funds to have longer deadlines and good games, that might be a good thing. But why not make a kickstarter for that then? Your publisher is Sekai, you have of alot publicity there. They can help you with increasing publicity for your kickstarter. It dosen't make sense.

Then again, if your just trying to make Steam-standard VNs for the others on steam to be introduced to Visual Novel scene, then I guess you kinda failed there. Flight Diary and the other actual VNs from Japan publishers that posted their games on Steam have it down pat.

16574749.review:
[h1]We're not in heaven but we've got angels by our side.[/h1]
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀[h1][b]Story[/b]:[/h1]
Kenta, a high school student, keeps thinking about monsters which haunt him. When a monster does appear in front of him on his way to school, he thinks it's the end of his life. Suddenly, two guardian angels, Sayaka and Hikari appear before him and eliminate the monster. Later on, they transfer to Kenta's school to keep him safe as their objective is to protect Kenta from the monsters.

                                                               [h1][b]Visuals[/b]:[/h1]
Compared to Sakura Spirit, this Visual Novel has a similar art style and has some improvements. The lighting on the backgrounds will change a bit so that the picture isn't just "still" and the backgrounds are more vibrant. The fight scenes are more interesting to watch with varied illustrations. There's a bit more action compared to the "2 girls standing and talking" kind of scenes.

[h1][b]Choices[/b]:[/h1]
You are given choices but most of them just lead to different dialogues that don't effect the story too much. Sometimes, you can choose what you want to know and eventually you will get to pick all the choices. 

[h1][b]Sound[/b]:[/h1]
The soundtrack is on a Youtube playlist, but there isn't an official steam release for the music (even though Sakura Spirit did). Other than that, the soundtrack fits the tone of the Novel, but I wouldn't really say it is anything interesting. As of 9/8/2015, there is now voice acting (only when certain characters talk).

[h1][b]Should you buy it?[/b][/h1]
If you liked Sakura Spirit, including the fanservice, you may like this one more. It has a present high school setting and still has some magic to it.

16571612.review:
After seeing all the positive reviews I finally decided to buy the game when it was on sale.
Sakura Angels is a Visual Novel, it resolves around a boy named "Kenta" who is tortured awake everyday from a trembling headache.
One day while walking to school, Kenta was out of nowhere attacked by a big, dark creature.
That is when two girls, Sayaka and Hikari steps into the light and saves him.

He has a hard time believing what's happened and that's when the story starts.

[b][h1]Negative:[/h1][/b]
[h1]It reuses the same backgrounds.[/h1]
The backgrounds are lazy and doesn't blend in with the story. If it's raining the sky will still be clear blue and sun will be shining.

[h1]It reuses the same music[/h1]
I think I only listened to 3 different tracks.

[h1]The music ends quickly[/h1]
It doesn't loop forever until the story progresses so if I'm reading the story, or go back to change my answer it can come to an end and I have to wait for the next scene.

[h1]No voiceover what so ever.[/h1]
Most VNs I've read usually have some form of voice over, whether it's just "hmpf", "HYA", "eto" or "nya" sounds. This had nothing.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story was short and I managed to play through it in only 3 hours on my first playthrough.

[b][h1]Positive:[/h1][/b]
[h1]The background[/h1]
The backgrounds are beautiful and well drawn, really managed to illustrate a city of Japan.

[h1]Characters[/h1]
I was really able to relate to Kenta, the writer really managed to give each character a good personality that was very realistic, it definitely felt like they were picked out of an anime.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story had some good moments, it was funny, sad and exciting.
I definitely did enjoy some parts of it and some I did not. But it did have it's moments.

[h1]fanservice[/h1]
The fanservice was alright. It's not much compared to what you'll see in any regular ecchi anime.
The art was good and it didn't look "fake".

[b][h1]overall:[/h1][/b]
I wouldn't recommend paying 10 euros for a 3 hour long game.
If it is on sale and you're really into adventure and magic or just really like anime stuff, maybe you could get some enjoyment out of this.
Or if you're thirteen and can't google boobies then sure spend money on this.

16534502.review:
[h1] "Is this my leg or yours? I can't tell." [/h1]

A fantasy/slice-of-life themed [b]Visual Novel[/b], which is quite short for its kind
but is the perfect lenght for the type of [b]VN[/b] it is.

The story's pretty simple, you've got your typical average protagonist boy Kenta, who starts having nightmares followed by morning migraine. Lucky for him, two magical girls appear before him to help him out! Story's not deep at all, and the antagonist of the story is also rather recycled, then again he/she/it didn't seem too important to the story. Heck, the story  itself isn't as  important as the main selling-point of the game. Which is...

"Plot". The one that we also refer to as "jumblies","melons" or anything else that bouncily comes to mind. This game has quite a lot of those, in different angles, and while not 100 percent accurately portrayed, they do make for a great sight for sore eyes. To summarise, the artstyle of this [b]VN[/b] is great to look at.

As for Background music.. it's decent. Decent enough not to annoy you during the playthrough. Can't promise you'll remember the tunes after a few days though. 
(Note. With the announcement of Voice Acting being implemented into the game in later time. For those who enjoy listening to voiced VNs by Japanese cast - this may become quite the cookie.)



All in all, I can recommend this VN for those who are looking to look at pretty pictures drawn in a certain Asian artstyle. 
If you're hoping for a deep story, this is not the VN for you. 
But if you're looking for a light (and [i]slightly[/i]) silly read with enough fanservice to get you through it - get this VN.

15757363.review:
Sakura Angels is a HUGE improvement over Sakura Spirits. That being said, it doesn't necessarily gets a "good" score from me, but rather a somewhat mediocre "good enough".

It has very nice drawings, an entertaining character study, but there are (again) no H-scenes and your choices hardly alter the story in an interesting way. The plot is very thin, and I wouldn't mind it that much actually if the writers had invested more time in writing independend routes for each of the 3 heroines, instead of 3 very short and generic ones for Hikari, Sayaka and a neutral one. Which leads me to another waste that is Yuzuki, which packs alongside her devilish hotness hints of an actual intriguing and deeply psychological backstory. Which isn't elaborates upon much, of course.

If Sakura Spirits desperately needed a patch to make any sense of anything it was trying to do, Sakura Angels only needed some fine tuning to actually be a quite decent casual western VN. Most definitely not a great one, mind you, for that there was not enough time and thought invested. Otherwise it could have gone far.

Again: The game has 3 endings in which you either become [i]sort-of-but-not-really-a-couple[/i] with Hikari or Sayaka, or neither of them (this third option should have been Yuzuki OR a harem ending, but what do I know, right?). I say [i]sort-of-but-not-really-a-couple[/i] because what we are really presented with is kiddies stuff: the furthest you'll see them getting intimate is a hug. Now, I don't think explicit sex is necessary to convey love through a VN, but at the very least the writer could have gone with a kiss to give us a romantic visual cue or sign of affection that, you know, shows us that someone likes the other person seriously. I would have been okay even with a kiss on the cheek, but no, this was probably considered XXX hardcore pornography. That was, in my humble opinion, just plain immaturity on Winged Cloud's part.

The potentiality of Sakura Angels was heavily lost on the decision to almost fully ignore Yuzuki as a 3 dimensional character. It would have been interesting if the creators actually gave quality some thought, to see a Yuzuki route that actually expanded on the little info we had on her, making her's the only that is told in the aftermath, [spoiler]when Hikari and Sayaka have to go, and how the main protagonist Kenta would deal with it.[/spoiler] But the writer didn't even care to establish if Yuzuki is human or not, nor for what entity the other girls are actually working for.

The climax of this VN is about how Kenta has difficulties concentrating enough but ends up saving the world anyway. The climax. Is. Literally. About. HOW. The protag. Can't concentrate. Or rather, forgot a detail of what he had to do to SAVE THE F***ING WORLD. You could have done SO MUCH to make it epic, but nope, that would have required creativity and investment. I could make a better climax on the spot, [spoiler]like, let's say, maybe a fight inside Kenta's head against "the evil", or a message from his badass ancestor on how to reseal the enemy.[/spoiler] It was just way to lame for such a great task as saving the world should be.

And let's talk about that: saving the world. Really? The bloathed ego of the writer couldn't content with, I dunno, the city or the region in which the VN plays? I think even going as far as saying that the main cast was fighting a [i]national threat[/i] would be making things way too dramatic for the proportions of this VN. If THE WHOLE WORLD really depended on Kenta and the evil sealed within his blood, don't you think [i]THEY[/i], whoever they are, would send their best and most capable magical girls, instead of Hikari and Sayaka? Who demonstrated several times that they weren't working together for too long.

Which brings me to another point.

The VN likes to play with the unsaid, that is, Hikari and Sayaka never reveal too much from where they are, who send them and their backstory. Everything supposedly top secret and to protect Kenta. See, such a technique isn't necessarily bad, but you need to know how to use it, otherwise you end up in a literary catastrophe like here. A [i]good[/i] video game example would be Guilty Gear Xrd's story mode and how a lot of technical nonsense terms are thrown around,- but eventually explained or presented in such a way it doesn't become a bother to the watcher. We had no idea who "the Conclave" was in the beginning, but from the way everybody talked about them and how they were presented TOLD us, the watchers, that they were up to no good. Who really cares about the "Schwarzschild Radial Limit", as long as it rocks in that one scene, giving the protag a chance to kick butts in a cool and flashy way? See, if you manage to suspend your audience's disbelief, you are doing it right! If you just omitt something that is ESSENTIAL to develop your characters deeper than the surface, you are writing yourself into a dead end.

Sakura Angels didn't need, but freely choose and is proud of being shallow. They had everything in their hands to make a  great casual western VN, even the experience of what not to do to make at the very least a decent one, and they wasted all their potential. For what I don't know. So many plot holes, so little character development (although the little bit they have ARE admittedly fun to read), so few routes to choose from, such a big letdown. 

Screw this game. It is WAY better than its predecessor, but I guess it's only good to fap to the pictures. And those you can get online for free.

Here's my two cents on this game/virtual/visual novel.

I got to know the dev team from our review on the first video.  This second game in a major increase on the story.  The first game had little to no options (I think one) as to how the story turned out.  This game, so far, seems to have some options which reveal different paths (pics) of the characters.

I have to say I enjoy the writing.  Sure, it's a little cheesy and long at times, but the writers do a good job at explaining what our hero is going through.  The artwork is obviously enjoyable (As a single man) and the choices i've faced so far unlock different outcomes.

In the end, Sakura Angels is what it is.  A virtual novel, with some VERY adult themes, and an enjoyable experience.  Here's what I promise you.  Buy the game, and you will have 5-10 people join your Steam Live Stream almost instantly but never admit they are watching it!  lol.
